section.title: Commands, Options, and Arguments
section.para: This chapter describes the recommended DocBook tags to use for commands, options, arguments, and other parameters related primarily to command-line examples and procedures. Exceptions are common, and each case must be evaluated individually. The purpose of this chapter is to provide a starting point for delivering consistent results as often as possible.

note.para: In all cases, see DocBook: The Definitive Guide and The IBM Style Guide for initial guidance.

section.title: Documenting Commands
section.para: Commands generally appear in two main scenarios: inline, as part of a general discussion or description of the command; or in a displayed block, as part of an example or procedural step. The second scenario often includes several command options that apply to the specific example or task.

In keeping with the philosophy of "never say never," commands almost always appear inside <command> tags. Even when used in <screen> or similar tags, commands need to be marked up to differentiate them from other text that may appear in a displayed block, for example, computer output. If they appear as part of body text, commands need to be differentiated from the surrounding text.
The Cloud documentation team has adopted the following practice for marking up commands and command options.

example.title: Marking up Commands in Body Text
example.para: Use the <command>ifconfig</command> command to configure network interfaces.
Use the ifconfig command to configure network interfaces.

example.title: Marking up Commands in Examples
example.para: Enter the following command to determine the status of the firewall:
Enter the following command to determine the status of the firewall: # service iptables status

note.para: The command prompt is only used in the displayed block example. This indicates to the reader the class of user required to run the command; whether that user requires root privileges or not.

section.title: Documenting Command Options

formalpara.title: Marking up Command Options in Body Text
formalpara.para: Use the appropriate DocBook tag to mark up options, arguments, values, and similar items when they appear in body text. In all cases, see DocBook: The Definitive Guide for initial guidance.

section.para: If no tag or solution presents itself, ask in #donuts on IRC, or raise a question in the DocBook XML Tag Usage Guide project.

formalpara.title: Marking up Command Options in Examples
formalpara.para: Do not include any specific markup for options in command examples, except for replaceable values.
